description:
Under början av 2018 beräknas 135 miljoner människor runt om i världen vara i behov av humanitärt stöd, och 815 miljoner människor i världen – en av nio – lida av hunger. 
 
Sida genomför årligen en humanitär allokeringsprocess, vari samtliga humanitära kriser analyseras utifrån de humanitära behoven. Allokeringsprocessen utmynnar i att de mest relevanta av strategiska partnerorganisationer att svara upp mot identifierade behov utväljs, vilket bland annat baseras på organisationernas relevans och effektivitet enligt iakttagelser från tidigare fältuppföljning. Det nu aktuella stödet till Action Against Hunger (AAH) baseras på Sidas humanitära allokeringsprocess, som färdigställdes under slutet av 2017. 

Aktuell insats bygger vidare på tidigare års stöd till AAH, som tidigare gick under namnet Action Contre La Faim (ACF). Sidas årliga stöd till AAH befästes 2014 då ett strategiskt partnerskap, genom ett treårigt avtal, signerades. Det treåriga avtalet föregicks av en djupdykande utvärdering, vilken bland annat framlyfte AAH:s goda expertis och renommé inom nutritionsområdet. Det treåriga avtalet förlängdes senare för att även inkludera 2017. Ett nytt treårigt avtal (2018-2020) föreslås nu för att möjliggöra en fortsatt strategisk ansats i relation och partnerskap med AAH. Det nu föreslagna stödet avses kompletteras med ytterligare stöd genom större ändringar av insatsen, i enlighet med Sidas insatshanteringsregel (§ 3.4.2), för åren 2018-2020. Kompletterande medelstillägg förutsätter att riksdagen anvisar nödvändiga finansiella medel samt baseras på bedömd relevans i kommande allokeringsprocesser. 

Totalt föreslås att 201 miljoner kronor allokeras till Action Against Hunger för implementeringen av humanitära hjälpinsatser i initialt 18 länder. För överblick och fördelning av stöd hänvisas till avtalets bilaga V (Budget summary).

Stödet utgår från fyra delkomponenter: 

1.	PROJEKTSTÖD. I 13 av länderna sker finansiering i form av projektstöd, där Sidas stöd går till specifika projekt med tydlig information kring projektets inriktning samt hur stödet kommer att implementeras. 

För 2019 och 2020 föreslås att 13 miljoner kronor respektive 8 miljoner kronor allokeras till AAH för att möjliggöra fleråriga stöd till två av de ovan nämnda projekten. Genom säkrad flerårig finansiering förväntas de två projekten uppnå mer långsiktiga och hållbara resultat. 

Ett tvåårigt stöd till Jemen har för avsikt att stärka AAH:s möjlighet att bygga starka och långsiktiga relationer med relevanta aktörer, med en förhoppning om att AAH kan etablera närvaro i föränderliga och svårtillgängliga områden. 

Ett treårigt stöd till Uganda, vilket genom en stegvis implementeringsmodell syftar till att stärka Sydsudanesiska flyktingars möjlighet till självförsörjning. Målet för AAH är att efter tre år fasa ut sitt stöd till berörda flyktingar, alternativt att de övergår till andra, mer långsiktiga stödformer. 

2.	PROGRAMSTÖD. I övriga fem länder har Sida för avsikt att i linje med den av regeringen antagna Grand Bargain, vilken är en överenskommelse som syftar till att effektivisera och minska kostnaderna av humanitär hjälp till nödlidande, ge stöd i form av en programbaserad ansats. Detta är en stödform som ger AAH möjlighet att flexibelt allokera stödet till ej förutbestämda humanitära behov inom länderna. Detta under förutsättning att insatserna faller inom ländernas respektive FN-ledda humanitära responsplaner samt de programdokument AAH har inkommit med till Sida. 

3.	RAPID RESPONSE MECHANISM. Av den initiala allokeringen utgör 35 miljoner kronor stöd i form av modellen Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM), vilket ger AAH flexibilitet att snabbt tillskjuta medel till nya insatser som syftar till att besvara plötsligt uppkomna, och förvärrade, humanitära behov. Sida måste dock, enligt avtal, godkänna AAH:s förslag på när och var RRM-medlen kan nyttjas, vilket kan göras inom 24 timmar. 

4.	METODSTÖD. 2,2 miljoner kronor av den initiala allokeringen går til
title: Action Against Hunger: Humanitärt stöd 2018-2020

description: Las becas de movilidad EM se enmarcan en la acción 2 del Programa Erasmus Mundus de la UE cuyo objetivo global es contribuir a mejorar y potenciar las perspectivas profesionales de los estudiantes, favorecer la comprensión intercultural mediante la cooperación con terceros países y contribuir al desarrollo sostenido de terceros países en el ámbito de la educación superior. La Unión Europea financia los costes de estancia y alojamiento de los estudiantes (1000 euros/mes a estudiantes de master y grado y 1500 ?/mes a estudiantes de posgrado), gastos de desplazamiento (variable), visado y seguro. La UGR aporta los costes de matrícula de estudiantes de movilidad temporal con estancias de hasta 10 meses. Esta aportación es la que se incluye en el presente informe.
title: BECA ERASMUS MUNDUS para cursar estudios de POSGRADO

description:
The Stories behind the Numbers: Testimonies from 13 Years Documenting Violence against
Since 2005, Yesh Din has been documenting human rights violations against Palestinians that persist as a result of 51 years of protracted occupation. Yesh Din has provided legal aid and monitored over 1,200 cases involving ideological offenses committed by Israeli civilians (usually settler violence). Thisnumber represents only cases in which complaints have been filed and Yesh Din documented many more offenses in which victims chose not to file a complaint. In this time, Yesh Din can attest to complicity by the Government of Israel (GOI) in failing in its obligation to protect the Palestinian civilians and their property living under its prolonged occupation and in enforcing the law on Israeli civilians.
title: The Stories behind the Numbers 2019

description: Im Jemen sind Schätzungen zufolge bei Vorhabenbeginn ca. 1,5 Mio. Kleinkinder und Schwangere bzw. stillende Frauen unterernährt. Das Vorhaben zielt auf eine Verbesserung der Gesundheitslage. Folgende Maßnahmen sollen unterstützt werden: (1) Ergänzungsnahrung für Kleinkinder unter 2 Jahren, (2) Spezialnahrung zur Behandlung von Mangelernährung von Kindern unter 5 Jahren und schwangeren bzw. stillenden Frauen. Es ist dafür ein deutscher Finanzierungsbeitrag in Höhe von bis zu 15 Mio. EUR vorgesehen. Mit diesem Finanzierungsbeitrag sollen 760.987 Mütter und Kinder erreicht werden. Die Umsetzung erfolgt in Direktleistung durch das Welternährungsprogramm (WEP).
title: Basisernährung Mutter- und Kindgesundheit V

description: The Australian Sports Outreach Program India is an Australian Government initiative implemented by the Australian Sports Commission that aims to contribute to building the capacity of organisations in India to deliver inclusive sports based programs that contribute to social development. ASOP India is planned around three core ‘pillars’: communicate - advocacy, social mobilisation and behaviour change communication strategies to enhance the perceived value of sport by key decision makers (i.e. parents, politicians, administrators, corporate managers, teachers and children); connect - facilitate opportunities for partner organisations to share resources and knowledge that will assist in achieving program goals; and collaborate- support India-based organisations to achieve S4D objectives through access to resources, technical know-how and funding support.
title: Australian Sports Outreach Program India

description: Award Description - The description for this item is Information Redacted

The deterioration in a variety of country contexts across Asia has led to rising numbers of civilian casualties and weapon-wounded patients being admitted to hospitals. Intensified humanitarian needs of displaced and conflict-affected individuals, as well as increased burdens on local health facilities, have resulted.   CIDA's contribution is supporting the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) to help meet the immediate clean water, shelter, medical care and material needs of displaced populations and the resident communities sheltering them. Activities also include supplying hospitals with supplies; technical support and supervision; staff training in war and clinical surgery; management training; facilities maintenance, and support for hospital blood banks and transfusion services.
title: Assistance to Displaced Populations in Asia and the Pacific - ICRC 2009

description: In early 2011, Caravan to Class built a school in Tedeini, Mali to give children in the village the opportunity to receive an education. Within the first year, school enrollment in Tedeini increased by 500 percent. Caravan to Class has hired certified teachers from Timbuktu to provide the best quality education. We also provide two free meals daily as well as school uniforms and other school supplies. This school currently impacts over 100 children and has a steadily increasing enrollment rate.
title: Basic nutrition for 100 school children in Mali

description: One way of building a field of research is to support international events that pursue to same objective. This grant will allow IDRC's Non Communicable Disease Policy (NCDP) program to provide core support to the following events: the 3rd Latin American and Caribbean Conference on Tobacco or Health in Lima (Peru), October 2011; the 15th World Conference on Tobacco or Health in Singapore, March 2012; the 13th World Congress on Public Health will be held in Addis Ababa (Ethiopia), April 2012; and the 22nd World Cancer Congress in Montreal (Canada), August 2012. The grant will also be used to enable NCDP awardees from low- and middle-income countries to attend the conferences. Priority will be given to those researchers who are presenting papers or posters.
title: Building the Field of Research on Non Communicable Disease Policy: Conference Support

RCC (Regional Cooperation Council) supports the political and economic development mutual cooperation and euro-atlantic integration of the South-East European countries. Finland has participated in the RCC activities and supported RCC since the establishme
nt of the organisation in 2008. The priority areas of RCC are economic and social development infrastructure justice and home affairs security cooperation building human capital and parilamentary cooperation. The secretariat based in Sarajevo supports deci
sion-making of RCC and facilitates cooperation projects of regional actors. Finland supports the secretariat of RCC with 50 000 euros annually. At the same time Finland is given the right to participate in RCC's decision-making. Through the secretariat Fin
land's support is also given to the administration of regional projects. The same amount of Finnish support is planned to be given annually. The support will be given still in 2014.

In the field of tobacco control it often happens that an opportunity to inform new or strengthen existing legislation arises requiring a rapid response on the part of the research community. This project will provide small-scale funding on a case-by-case basis to address such opportunities. Funded activities could take the form of quick analyses or small surveys to provide policymakers with the necessary evidence on which to base their decisions. The fund may also be used to support the application of new learning to existing interventions or policies, or to complement the advocacy efforts of other donors. A modest amount has been set aside to support the production of issue papers on emerging topics that are relevant to global tobacco control.
title: Rapid Response Fund for Opportunities to Advance Tobacco Control

Hurricane Matthew could have devastating impacts in Haiti, as the country has not experienced a storm of this magnitude since 1954.  CARE is coordinating with the government to help people evacuate from areas at extreme risk. We are providing meals and supplies such as water bladders to provide clean drinking water, hygiene kits, tarps and blankets  to people in shelters. CARE is appealing for immediate funds to ramp-up our emergency response and support the longer-term recovery of Haiti.
title: Haiti Hurricane Matthew Emergency Response Fund

description: Insatsen avser en Specialist Development Programme (SPD) tjänst. SDP-programmet syftar till att stärka UNDP: s kapacitet att stödja länder för att göra agenda 2030 en realitet med ett särskilt fokus på krisländer och den humanitära utvecklingsnexusen. Specialisten ger rådgivning, analys, samordnings- och kvalitetssäkring till Country Director. Insatsen bidrar till genomförandet av Resultstrategin för kapacitetsutveckling och utbyten 2014-2017 och efterföljande strategi (2018-2021) och ska bidra till följande mål: 1) Ökat antal kvalificerade svenskar i av regeringen prioriterade internationella och regionala organisationer och institutioner och 2) Breddad svensk resursbas för det multilaterala, bilaterala och regionala biståndet genom särskilda kompetensutvecklings- och utbildningsprogram program för yngre personer.
title: SPD UNDP 2017 Egypt GB

description:
Proyecto marco para las misiones de auditoria que se llevarán a cabo en Colombia en 2018

Se se realizarán las auditorias a los 5 clientes en Colombia en 2018 (COMSAB, FCC, COMEPCAFE,ECOLSIERRA y COMCACAOT)

The Agroindustrial Cooperative of Palmito Apropal, Agriterra's client since 2013, has achieved organic certification for a first group of partners representing an approx. of 170 Hás those that produce an approximate of 11 containers per year out of a total of 40 conventional containers. It is expected to achieve a replication effect with more farmers who can achieve organic certification in a period no longer than 3 years. The expectation is that as they perceive the benefits of producing organic palm in terms of their individual income, as well as that of the Organization, this way of cultivating will spread throughout the Organization, taking care of the environment and strategically differentiating from the environment. competition.
This Project aims to strengthen the path already advanced in productive-organic, strategic and commercial issues, as well as to continue emphasizing work in governance that is still a weakness within the Organization.
title: Auditorías Colombia

description: This project aims to protect the human rights of vulnerable children in targeted communities in Afghanistan. It seeks to provide education stakeholders with fundamental skills, knowledge and strategies to ensure safe learning environments. The project also supports gender specific techniques that address child rights and the different child protection needs of girls and boys.  Project activities include: (1) training teachers, children, families, school councils, communities and government officials to develop child-protection systems and promote children's rights at local, district, provincial and national levels in Afghanistan; (2) implementing a community-based child protection model by developing child protection referral systems, facilitating community outreach, and training community leaders on how to respond to identified cases; (3) supporting the establishment of safe, violence-free community centres in existing community structures for children and youth, with an emphasis on girls; (4) promoting initiatives that allow vulnerable children to benefit from recreation, educational play, and psychosocial support; and (5) training volunteers to run the centers and use child-to-child methodology to equip and educate children on how to protect themselves and advocate for their own protection.
title: Enhancing Protection for Afghan Children (EPAC)

description: Award Description - The description for this item is Public Diplomacy Programs
Description information is not available for this item

March 2018 - Niger continues to face significant humanitarian challenges related to food insecurity, malnutrition, and forced displacement. The expansion of the conflict in Nigeria has led to more than 400,000 people in need and the highest levels of food insecurity in the country. It is expected that humanitarian needs remain high in Niger’s Diffa region throughout 2018.  With GAC’s support, Development and Peace and its partners are addressing the urgent humanitarian needs of up to 48,330 people in the Diffa region. Project activities include: (1) constructing sanitary facilities that accommodate the unique needs of women and men, benefiting up to 12,000 people; (2) distributing feminine kits, benefiting up to 3,000 women and adolescent girls; (3) distributing materials necessary for construction or repair of shelters, benefiting up to 21,000 people; and (4) providing cash-for-work and cash grants activities, benefiting up to 10,500 people.
title: Niger - Humanitarian Assistance in Diffa Region - Development and Peace 2018-2019

description: Tiden kring födelsen, den perinatala perioden, är den tid i livet som årligen omfattar 300,000 mödradödsfall, 2,6 miljoner dödfödda barn och 2,6 miljoner nyfödda, som dör under den första levnadsmånaden. Vidare är de första 1000 dagarna av livet, före och efter födseln, den period med de mest djupgående konsekvenserna för hälsa på kort och lång sikt. Perioden från början av graviditeten till två års ålder ger således en unik möjlighet att skapa en solid grund för överlevnad, hälsa, tillväxt och kognitiv utveckling.Det finns idag en gedigen kunskap om att så kallade faciliterade grupper, som arbetar tillsammans är en effektiv social innovation för att framgångsrikt identifieraoch agera mot lokala problem för förbättrad perinatal hälsa och överlevnad. Trots att metoden förespråkas av WHO har ingen storskalig implementering prövats. Det finns heller ingen praktisk vägledning om hur denna sociala innovationen ska implementeras eller vilka effekter som kan förväntas. Om den sociala innovationen implementeras eftertänksamt har den en stor kapacitet att stärka hälsosystemets förmåga till förbättringsarbete och stärka dess förmåga till ansvarsfull styrning. Det föreslagna nätverket SUSTAIN (Scaling Up Survive and Thrive Action Interventions) avser att utveckla, söka finansiering för och implementera den en denna sociala innovation i stor skala i Etiopien och Rwanda. Under den treårsperiod vi söker finansiering för avser vi fortsatt stärka vår kompetens och gemensamma kunskapsbank för att öka möjligheterna för att genomföra ett transdiciplinärt projekt genom återkommande workshops på föreslagna teman. Den planerade SUSTAIN innovationen syftar till att dokumentera och utvärdera hälsoutfall, kostnad och process samt att producera riktlinjer och material för att använda metoden även i andra länder. Projektet är inriktat mot såväl primärvårdsnivå, sjukhus och administratörer med ansvar för hälso- och sjukvårdsfrågor och planering i de ingående studieområdena.Innovationen antas bidra till att skapa bättre fungerande hälsosystem på lokal- och distriktsnivå, och ge redskap för att aktivt och systematiskt arbeta för förbättring av vården av mödrar samt överlevnaden, hälsa och utveckling hos deras ofödda och födda barn. Projektet inkluderar mycket väl meriterade forskare med kompletterande kunskaper från olika forskningsfält och lärosäten i Sverige, Etiopien, Rwanda, England och Tyskland. I projektets globala referensgrupp medverkar framstående representanter för UNICEF och Världsbanken.
title: Scaling Up Survive and Thrive Action Interventions (SUSTAIN). Implementering av en evidensbaseradebaserade social innovation för kvinnors och barns hälsa i Etiopien och Rwanda

description: Through the Service Delivery, Quality Improvement and Health Systems Strengthening Program, EGPAF will scale up high quality, comprehensive HIV prevention and treatment services at 150 health facilities in seven target districts. The program has identified and will address the service delivery gaps that prevent quality HIV prevention, care and treatment services.  EGPAF will improve the delivery of services, particularly the implementation of Option B+. The expected reduction in new HIV infections and morbidity and mortality will be realized through increasing the effectiveness, sustainability, equity and efficiency of district-based planning, budgeting and implementation processes in zones and districts, and supporting evidence-based prevention, care and treatment interventions at the facility level.  This program will be fully aligned with district health service and budget planning processes to ensure full harmonization and district level ownership.  Elements of this program include increasing alignment with government, and mutual accountability through directly funding zones or districts through sub-grants, while carefully monitoring performance, providing direct financial and technical support to strengthen planning, budgeting, financial and expenditure processes, and integrating strategic information more effectively and directly in district planning. This program supports the provision of needed HIV services, promotes improved health services through strengthening leadership and governance, the health workforce, information systems, laboratory and other health system components at the district level by supporting specific critical health services across multiple disease areas consistent with priorities identified in Malawi’s Health Sector and HIV Strategic Plans.
title: Mechanism 14113 - District Health System Strengthening and Quality Improvement for Service Delivery in Malawi under PEPFAR

description:
The current security context in the Lake Chad Basin linked to the Boko Haram conflict continues to drive an escalating
humanitarian crisis in Diffa region in Niger (FewsNet and Cadre Harmonisé currently have the region of Diffa in IPC
phase 3 (crisis) includingwith humanitarian assistance, until at least January 2017). As of September 2016, the region
of Diffa hosts 302,387 IDPs, refugeesand returnees alone.1 According to authorities from the Diffa Region, even
though more than 80 per cent of the population of Bosso, who became displaced after the 3 June attacks, has
returned home; commercial activities remain largely paralyzed due to continuedinsecurity affecting the Lake Chad
Basin area and the ongoing #Emergency State# in the region. People are in desperate need for critical items and basic
food assistance. As the crisis worsens, Diffa is facing an influx of refugees fleeing either the conflict inthe surrounding
countries or the increasing food insecurity. The IDP population is showing little sign of returning despite the efforts of
the government and the Niger Military#s need to create a population free area between the N1 and the Nigerian
border has further increased the number of IDPs. In early 2016 the IDP/refugee/returnee populationwas estimated
at 93,343 refugees, 72,549 returnees and 58,000 IDPs. Following the Boko Haram attacks and occupation of Bosso in
June 2016, the number of IDPs, returnees and refugees was then increased to 280,000 people. Much of the displaced
populationis living in makeshift and unofficial spontaneous camps, often next to N1 route and living with or in most
cases around the host communities (Diffa#s population is 310,000 people - 2012census) resulting in high levels of
vulnerability for both IDP andhost communities and leading to further scarcity of already rareresources.
Food Security needs are acute, affecting both the IDP/refugee populations as well as the host communities. Current
estimates by OCHA are that only 65% of people in need of foodassistance in the Diffa region are currently receiving
support, with a total 454,000 people in need of food assistance2. This is also leading to a worsening malnutrition
crisis with Global acute malnutrition (GAM) rates exceeding the 15 per cent emergency threshold at 17.1% in the
Diffa region (OCHA 06/04/2016)3. Access to food due to lack of stocks, production, income, and employment
opportunities is a critical issue for IDPs and refugees as the vast majority depend on food assistance. Oxfam
assessments carried out in October and November 2016 reveal people engaging in disturbing irreversible coping
mechanisms in order to make money to purchase food in markets such as selling jewellery and productive assets,
marryingtheir girls at a young age, and borrowing money to buy food and critical items. Reports of women engaging
in emergency sex to access money are also widespread. The lack of livelihoods opportunities in the chronically poor
Diffa region is critical; host communities and pre-existingdisplaced populations already faced high levels of food
insecurity and lacked livelihoods. The burden of new arrivals is aggravating this situation (OCHA 07/06/2016). Access to food assistance is key for households to increase their dietary diversity, reduce irreversible negative coping
strategies (such as the sale of productive assets), and reduce prevalence of severe acute malnutrition.  Through this proposed project, Oxfam is looking at providing this essential food assistance to 500 vulnerable
households in settlements along the N1 route, in Diffa region.
title: CO-NIGER

description:
The project is continuation of a project between the Cameroonian Association of Home Economics Counsellors ACESF-CA and the Finnish Martha Association. The Family Federation of Finland will join to strengthen comprehensive sexuality education (CSE) among y
oung girls and poor women. In Cameroon 37.5% of the population of 8.1 million people live below the poverty threshold set at 931 CFAF (141 ?) per day for adult. Women are the most affected by this poverty and living conditions of their families. On the oth
er hand the current life and future of the young girls are influenced by sexist discriminations which result from poor sociocultural practices. Often underprivileged women have very thin knowledge on nutrition the nutritive value of local foods and sexual 
health. The overall objective of the project is to contribute to an increased empowerment of poor women and girls in families and the Cameroonian society.The project is composed of four strategic axes: 1. Nutrition education of poor women2. Improve the inc
ome of beneficiaries (women with low income)3. Promote gender equality and the empowerment of girls of the Home Economics field through CSE and entrepreneurship training4. Create a resource and business centre for ACESF-CA to serve better its beneficiaries
The direct beneficiaries are: 720 poor women who will take part in the training sessions on nutrition; 210 underprivileged women who will be accompanied in the drafting and execution of their business plans; 900 girls of the Home Economics field grouped un
der 12 ACESF-CA/SU clubs who learn reading CSE and entrepreneurship; 12 regional animators and 60 volunteer members chosen from Home Economics professionals who are members of ACESF-CA who will take refresher courses in pedagogy on CSE nutrition and entrep
reneurship.The intervention zone of the project will comprise six regions: Bafoussam Bamenda Bertoua Douala Maroua and Yaounde. The project partners are Martat ACESF-CA and Family Federation of Finland in collaboration with CAMNAFAW and the external servic
es of the Ministry of Women Empowerment and the Family (MINPROFF) and the Ministry of Secondary Education (MINESEC).
title: Nutrition Education promotion of gender equality and empowerment of poor girls and women in Cameroon

description: Child marriages and teenage pregnancies remain high in Malawi. The country has one of the highest rates of child marriages in the world. UNICEF estimates that 9% and 46% are married by 15 and by 18 years old respectively. Apart from certain related harmful cultural practices, teenage pregnancies are one of the main causes of child marries. Teenage pregnancies remain high because of high unmet need for contraceptives, peer pressure and other harmful cultural practices like Kusasa fumbi (interpreted as shaking off the inexperience in sex by doing it) and kutomera (Some worthy community members choosing a girl child as a wife when she is still a toddler).
title: Standing Up For Adolescents (SU4A)

description:
The impact will be safer and enhanced access to socioeconomic opportunities for communities in PNG. The project is expected to produce benefits for remote rural populations as well as the national and international population. The outcome will be the environment for safe and economic shipping routes provided by NMSA.

Outputs:
Outputs include (i) replaced, installed and maintained navaids, (ii) improved safety information infrastructure, (iii) improved maritime safety practice of communities, and (iv) efficient project management and capacity development provided.

Output 1: Replaced, installed and maintained navaids. NMSA will replace 99 existing navaids and install 33 additional navaids. These are outlined in the NMSA's work plan with site selection criteria. [Scope and Technical Report (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2)]. To determine priorities, the plan uses engineering aspects, including relationship with PNG's existing navaids network, ship traffic density, and environmental condition. The proposed project will conduct a feasibility study that includes investigation of the navaids' local environment and conduct due diligence assessments. Where a need is identified, engineering design will incorporate measures for adapting to climate change impacts to ensure sustainable maintenance. [ADB. 2012. PNG Climate Change Vulnerability Assessment of Navigational Infrastructure. Manila (TA 6420)].  Communities will participates in a community engagement program to monitor and secure good condition of navaids based on the practice of the previous project [ADB. 2000. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to Papua New Guinea for the Rehabilitation of the Maritime Navigation Aids System Project. Manila (Loan 1754)].

Output 2: Improved safety information infrastructure. NMSA will produce a modern series of paper and electronic navigational charts (ENC) after recompiling existing PNG navigational chart portfolios in cooperation with Australian Hydrographic Service (AHS). [NMSA and Australian Hydrographic Service have a partnership to conduct hydrographic surveys and produce navigational charts]. NMSA will contract out a large scale hydrographic survey and provide data to AHS for producing nautical charts and ENC for seven ports. [ Kulili Harbour; Schlangen Harbor, Wasu; Bugoiya Harbor, Misima Island; Panabwal Group; Deboyne Islands; Yanaba Island, Egum Atoll; and Dawson Strait]. Also, NMSA will extend the automatic identification system (AIS) network by installing AIS transponders and base stations in at least five sites and relocating three existing stations. The project will confirm details and configuration of each site prior to the commencement of civil works. Also, tide gauges will be installed in four major ports [Three tide gauges were installed in Port Moresby, Alotau, and Lae by June 2012. Proposed additional sites are in Daru in Western Province, Madang, Buka in Bougainville Islands, and Manus Islands.] to measure changes in the sea level and contribute to the growing database of climate change and sea level rise information.

Output 3: Improved maritime safety practice of communities. NMSA will provide maritime safety awareness activities among the general public and in targeted rural and remote communities to change people's perceptions about maritime safety and improve small craft safety practices. The activities will include a well planned media campaign and production of high quality information materials aimed at different audiences (e.g., children and adults). Specific small craft safety training activities and materials designed specifically for women will be designed with advice from the NMSA Women in Maritime Association.

Output 4: Efficient project management and capacity development provided. The project will help NMSA establish a project implementation unit (PIU) to implement and manage all activities funded by the project. The PIU will be s
title: Maritime and Waterways Safety Project

description: This action will have twin aims 1. to prevent violence and 2. to support children who have experienced abuse or violence. In order to address the interlocking circles of violence which affect the majority of children and are particularly acute for the most vulnerable. the action will seek to build capacities and establish new social norms in all spheres up to district level and to take the learning from that to inform the next steps in national roll out of the Plans on Violence Against Children and Most Vulnerable Children.

description: Funding under this investment  provides support through the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) to improve the availability, quality and use of data on children with disabilities. UNICEF will partner with the Washington Group on Disability Statistics (WG) to complete a set of survey questions to provide international standardised data on children with disabilities. This funding will also support the development of a second set of survey questions to understand the barriers and facilitators to children with disability accessing quality education. The survey is intended to be used to capture statistics on children with disability attending school and those who are not. Once completed these survey questions will be used to improve data collection on children with disabilities in UNICEF’s Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), one of the largest global sources of internationally comparable data on the situation of children and women. Funding also supports the production manuals which will support the implementation of these two surveys and provide advice on how to design and plan child disability data collection programs from start to finish. UNICEF will work with National Statistics offices (NSO) to ensure: 1) they have the skills to use both surveys to collect the right data; 2) they can analyse the results to inform future policies and programmes; and 3) to promote the use of the surveys. UNICEF will prioritise implementation in the Asia-Pacific region. The total value of this investment is $1.5 million over 2 years, starting 2013-14.
title: Improving data on children

description: GAVI’s support for new vaccines presents an opportunity for countries to not only implement vaccines that protect against diseases causing substantial morbidity and/or mortality, but also to build upon the vaccine investments in order to increase immunisation coverage rates, and strengthen routine immunisation services and primary health care systems. WHO recommends that all GAVI-eligible countries at risk of yellow fever incorporate yellow fever vaccines into their national immunisation programmes. Countries at higher risk that have not to date introduced the vaccine into EPI (five of 32 GAVI-eligible countries in Africa) are encouraged to apply for GAVI support. This includes: Ethiopia, Mauritania, Sudan, South Sudan and Uganda.
title: New vaccine support (NVS) for YF

description: The Australia-Pacific Technical College (APTC) was established in July 2007, following the Prime Minister's announcement at the 2006 Pacific Islands Forum.  The APTC is a unique development program delivering internationally recognised technical and vocational programs in targeted industry sectors in the Pacific region. The APTC delivers Australian Certificate III, IV and Diploma level training in the following industry sectors: automotive, manufacturing, construction and electrical, tourism and hospitality and health and community services.   APTC's objectives are to: support skill development in the Pacific, in response to national, regional and international labour market requirements;	provide qualifications that will present opportunities for Pacific Islanders to access international labour markets; and	increase productivity of individuals and organisations in the targeted industries and sectors. The total value of this multi-country initiative is $152.2 million over 6 years, starting 2010-11.
title: Australia-Pacific Technical College Stage 2

description: (USAID Latin America and Caribbean Regional):  .Intended to strengthen design, implementation, monitoring, and evaluation of USAID's primary education, workforce development, higher education, and youth programs in the LAC region, this activity will provide technical assistance services to respond to the Latin America and Caribbean Regional Program (LAC/RP) and field mission demands. These areas of support may include: research, analysis, assessment, monitoring and evaluation services, and training, and will be defined on a needs-basis. With FY 2018 funds, this mechanism will support the design and implementation of LAC regional workshops and training to share best practices in programming and learn about relevant new developments and cutting edge research with USAID education technical staff in the region. This will include a training on youth workforce development designed for the unique environment in LAC and focused specifically on interventions that equip out-of-school and at-risk youth with foundational skills such as literacy, numeracy, and social-emotional skills. Funds also will support assessments and evaluations to inform future education programming design under USAID's 2018 Education Policy. By strengthening design, implementation, and oversight of USAID education interventions in the LAC region, this activity helps to ensure that investments in improving education outcomes made by U.S. taxpayers are effective..
title: EDU: Education Support Contract

description: The development objective of the Senegal River Basin Multi-purpose Water Resources Development Project is to enhance regional integration among the riparian countries of the Senegal River Basin through Organisation pour la Mise en Valeur du fleuve Senegal - Senegal River Basin Organization (OMVS) for multi-purpose water resources development to foster growth including improved community livelihoods. The restructuring is being done to affect the following: a) changes to the development objectives and the results framework; b) the cancellation of some technical assistance activities under components two and three of the project; c) the change in implementation arrangements for the executing agency in Mali; and d) an extension of the closing date from September 8, 2011 to March 31, 2013. Finally, the 1.5 year extension of the project closing date is required to compensate for delays in project effectiveness which resulted in at least a 6-month reduction in the implementation period and also for delays as a result of the suspensions of the Islamic Republic of Mauritania and the Republic of Guinea from World Bank business.
title: Senegal River Basin Multi-purpose Water Resources Development Project

description: Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.
title: Vulnerable Children

description: In Chad, 86% of women do not have a skilled health professional assisting them in childbirth, leading to increased risks of disability and death for the mother and newborn in the event of complications. Chad’s poor Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) has shown no signs of improvement since 1990 and is significantly off-track for meeting the MDG5 target. This project will improve maternal health for vulnerable women in north N’Djamena by improving community antenatal awareness, service delivery, advocating for regionally improved birthing practices through the government taskforce, and building the capacity of Chadian midwives through expert training.
title: Addressing Chad’s off-track MDG5 status by encouraging and implementing safe birthing practices

description:
Projektförslaget bygger på en pågående insats i Mali 2013-2015 ’Strengthening Civil Society contributions to peace, security and development’. Genom denna insats utvecklades en strategisk vision för det civila samhällets deltagande i fred- och försoningsprocessen för nationell samhörighet genom en stor konferens i september 2015 med ett brett deltagande från civila samhället, maliska ministerier, academia och internationella partners. 

Syftet med det nya projektet är att stärka det civila samhällets organisationer (CSOs) för att på så vis bidra till fred och säkerhet och därmed utveckling. Genom att öka CSOs möjligheter att förstå sig på och bevaka människors uppfattning om trygghet och säkerhet i sin omgivning och förmedla detta till beslutsfattare i landet, förutser man ett bredare inflytande av det civila samhället på Malis policyramverk och en mer inkluderande fredsprocess. Detta ska uppnås genom att bland annat utbilda ca 100 representanter från det civila samhället runt om i landet för bättre bevakning och analys och genom att diskutera trygghet och säkerhetsfrågor via två stora konferenser. Ökad allmän kunskap om befolkningens uppfattning vad gäller trygghet och säkerhetsfrågor vill man ska stärkas genom en bred media kampanj och genom att försöka påverka beslutsfattare inom både lokala och nationella nätverk. Det övergripande målet sammanfattas sålunda: ’To improve post-conflict national and local policies to address the safety and security challenges for the population, through increased integration of civil society perspectives on these challenges’

Efter statskuppen i mars 2012 har Mali genomlevt ett instabilt säkerhetsläge. För att uppnå fattigdomsminskning, vilket är den viktigaste prioriteringen för Malis regering och därmed det övergripande målet för det svenska utvecklingssamarbetet med Mali, måste säkerhetssituationen stabiliseras. I maj och juni i år skrev de stridande parterna under ett Fredsavtal. För att implementerandet av fredsavtalet ska bli så legitimt som möjligt, är det viktigt att även inkludera det civila samhället. Projektet stödjer detta genom att utbilda CSOs från de olika regionerna i landet inom kartläggningsmetoder, analys och rapportering för att på så vis stärka det civila samhällets engagemang då beslut som påverkar fredsprocessen ska fattas. 

Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI) är ett Stockholmsbaserat, självständigt institut som etablerades 1966 och som även har kontor i Beijing och Washington. SIPRI arbetar med forskning inom konflikt, vapen, vapenkontroll och nedrustning. Organisationen tillhandahåller data, analyser och rekommendationer till beslutsfattare, forskare och media. Fördelen med att välja SIPRI som partner för denna insats är att SIPRI redan har erfarenhet av samarbete med det civila samhället i Mali. Innan det Sidastödda projektet 2013-2015 genomförde SIPRI ett tre-årigt projekt som bl.a. involverade fem länder söder om Sahara, däribland Mali och dess civila samhälle. Projektet, som hette ’Africa, Security and Governance’, fokuserade på betydelsen av det civila samhället för kontraterrorism. Sida har även sedan tidigare positiv erfarenhet av att arbeta med SIPRI genom projektet ’Conflict Sensitive Logistics and Ethical Transporation Clearinghouse’ där det övergripande målet var att få målgrupperna för projektet att minska sin användning av företag som sysslar med vapenhandel. Sida noterade att insatsen var framgångsrik både gällande resultat fastställda i avtalet samt rapportering till Sida vid avtalad tidpunkt. 

SIPRI har även erfarenhet av arbete med La Coalition Nationale de la Société Civile pour la Paix et la Lutte contre la Prolifération des Armes Légères (CONASCIPAL) som är en paraplyorganisation för cirka 20 av civila samhällets organisationer i Mali. CONASCIPAL har sedan det startades 1998 organiserat en mängd konferenser och möten kring fred, säkerhet och lätta vapen. 

Projektet bygger på SIPRIs analytiska förmåga, opartiska for
title: SIPRI Mali 2016-2018 Civila Samhället

description: This project is training Maijuna indigenous people of the Peruvian Amazon how to raise native stingless bees as a sustainable income source. The Maijuna live in one of the most biologically rich places on Earth and this project provides them with an alternative source of income from other more destructive economic activities such as logging and overhunting. Your support will help to empower the Maijuna to conserve their heavily forested ancestral lands for future generations!
title: Beekeeping with Indigenous People in the Amazon

description: This project aims to strengthen the protection and exercise of sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) for women and adolescents in Honduras, El Salvador and Nicaragua and the sharing of experiences on SRHR in the region.  Project activities implemented in the three countries include: (1) regional monitoring of advances of SRHR in line with the recommendations of international human rights mechanisms; (2) coordination and capacity building of national governments and other local actors on SRHR; (3) high level policy dialogue and exchange of best practices on SRHR among the three countries.  Specific activities implemented in both El Salvador and in Nicaragua, include: (1) holistic sexual education and sexual and reproductive health attention in schools, in coordination with the respective ministries of education and health; (2) creation of early alert systems to prevent violence against children and adolescents; (3) capacity building to improve holistic attention for victims of sexual and gender based violence at community and family levels; and (4) cultural and sports activities to empower girls and change discriminatory attitudes and practices.
title: Protecting Girls and Adolescents from Sexual Violence, Teenage Pregnancies and Early Unions

description: The objective of the Agro-Pastoral Recovery Project (APRP) for Central African Republic is to increase productivity and production of selected food crops and livestock species in the project area. This project paper seeks the approval of the Executive Directors to provide a Credit in an amount of SDR 8.3 million (US$13.09 million equivalent) and a grant in an amount of SDR 6.8 million (US$10.71 million equivalent) to the Central African Republic (CAR) for an emergency APRP. In October 2010, the Government of CAR (GoCAR) requested assistance from the World Bank to help with its ongoing efforts to fight against food insecurity. Knowing that supplemental International Development Association (IDA) funds amounting to US$20 million were being made available to CAR, the World Bank gave its consent to the preparation of an emergency agricultural development project to consolidate and extend the gains achieved under the emergency Food Crisis Response Project (FCRP) that was approved in July 2008. The credit and grant will help to finance the costs associated with the implementation of the government's strategy to tackle chronic food insecurity, with a particular focus on the south-western part of the country, which has significant agricultural potential but where malnutrition is widespread and where unemployment rates are high following the closing of many mining activities. The APRP will help to increase incomes and safeguard food security of rural households by supporting activities designed to: (i) increase production of selected crops and livestock products; (ii) strengthen institutions and build capacity among targeted stakeholders including particularly farmers and their organizations; and (iii) carry out project coordination and management activities, including project administration, financial management, procurement, monitoring and evaluation of project performance a
title: CAR-Agro-Pastoral Recovery Project

description:
Ce projet constitue la deuxième phase du projet d’aide alimentaire programmée de 2016 exécuté par OXFAM et son partenaire local Mahlahle pour atténuer les effets négatifs de la sécheresse liée à El Nino dans le district de Panda, province d’Inhambane. L’objectif général du projet est d’élargir la couverture du projet d’aide alimentaire programmée approuvé en septembre 2016. Plus précisément, le projet vise à :

- Augmenter l'aide alimentaire à 790 familles les plus vulnérables du district de Panda pour une période de trois mois pour couvrir la période de pénurie alimentaire.
- Renforcer l'autonomie et la résilience des familles en mettant en œuvre des activités de récupération post – urgence et de réduction des risques de catastrophe.
- Soutenir l’autonomisation des communautés couvertes par le projet, en particulier les femmes, en termes de nutrition.
title: Réponse à la sécheresse liée à El Niño au Mozambique – Phase 2

description: Le programme de Trias au Burkina Faso cherche à renforcer six unions et fédérations agricoles dans les filières riz et oignons de niveau départemental et/ou provincial au Centre Nord et dans le Sud-Ouest du Pays ainsi que d’assurer leur liaison vers l’accès au crédit à travers l’appui d’une institution de microfinance rurale. En deuxième ligne, deux faîtières et la plateforme paysanne nationale seront appuyées pour assurer entre autres la remontée des préoccupations de plaidoyer jusqu’au niveau national, voir même régional. Ces organisations membres (OM) ont été choisies en fonction de leur volonté de travailler sur la bonne gouvernance et de contribuer à une société inclusive et un environnement durable. Le programme cible 6.075 bénéficiaires directs et atteindra indirectement la totalité des membres de ces OM estimé à 258.000 personnes dont 35% femmes et 25% de jeunes d’ici fin 2021. Sur base d’un diagnostic de capacités et les plans de développement organisationnel élaboré par les OM en phase préparatoire, Trias propose avec ce programme de se focaliser principalement sur le développement de leadership au sein des OM, l’entreprenariat rural, l’accès au financement, la promotion des techniques de production durables (e.a. agro-écologie) ainsi que le développement de réseautage et de coopération. Les femmes, les jeunes ainsi que les opportunités d’investissement en TICs recevront une attention particulière tout au long du programme. Ce programme s’inscrit fortement dans la complémentarité entre acteurs et fait appel à multiples partenariats. Au total 7 parties prenantes et une multitude de synergies opérationnelles et stratégiques entre acteurs belges serviront d’effet levier dans l’atteinte des résultats.
title: PROG 2017-2021_Outcome_Burkina Faso

description:
Resultatlabbet är en flerårig satsning där ramorganisationerna (och eventuellt andra svenska CSO) konkret testar och utvecklar metoder och arbetssätt kring resultatstyrning. Utvecklingsarbetet tar sin utgångspunkt i den befintliga verksamheten och/eller planerade nya insatser/partnerskap där man vill utveckla och testa för organisationen nya metoder. 

Syftet med resultatlabbet är att medverkande organisationer utvecklar arbetet med flexibla och adaptiva/anpassade metoder i resultatstyrningsarbetet, gärna tillsammans med partnerorganisationer, och att skapa en plattform för gemensamt lärande mellan de organisationer som deltar och mellan dessa organisationer och Sida kring detta.
title: Resultatlabb - metodutveckling för resultatstyrning CSO

description: This project takes the Youth Bank methodology first developed in Northern Ireland and adapts it to Mozambique. In various countries of the world YouthBank organizations have succeeded in mobilizing young people from different backgrounds and forging collaboration and joint action, usually involving local grantmaking. Youth Bank Chimoio (YBC) is the first attempt to launch a youth-led grant making programme in Mozambique. YBC is run by young people, for young people. The grants component will stimulate social and economic entrepreneurship and local resource mobilisation (volunteering and financial) that could be a basis for establishing a form of community foundation. The project aims to enable more than 2,500 young men and women to plot their own paths out of poverty and through the project we will establish a model that in principle can be widely replicated in Mozambique.
title: Youth Bank Chimoio: enabling 2,500 young women and men to improve their livelihoods and pioneering a new movement for social and economic entrepreneurship in Mozambique

description: Award Description - The description for this item is Non-proliferation

El proyecto La Blanca, en el que he tenido la suerte de participar y colaborar gracias alPrograma de Cooperación 2013, es un proyecto que desde el año 2004, con un equipo interdisciplinar de la Universidad de Valencia, Universidad Politécnica de Valencia y la Universidad San Carlos de Guatemala, dirigido por Cristina Vidal Lorenzo y Gaspar Muñoz Cosme, está trabajando para recuperar la antigua ciudad maya de La Blanca, que ha permanecido abandonada y sepultada por más de mil años en la selva subtropical guatemalteca. Dentro de los objetivos generales del proyecto es conocer la historia y arquitectura de este asentamiento maya y la relación comercial y política con otros centros urbanos cercanos, como es el caso de El Chilonché. Los de la campaña de este año 2013, fueron continuar con las investigaciones de la campaña anterior, como se hizo con la excavación de la subestructura oeste del palacio de La Blanca, documentar el estado del templo de la pirámide del grupo sur, y realizar una rápida intervención de restauración en los restos de los muros, así como restituir la cubierta de palma, deteriorada, por otra con materiales de apoyo más resistentes, y cambiar la hoja antigua por otras nuevas. También continuamos con la investigación del grupo oeste, con la realización de pozos de sondeos en puntos donde podían darnos información relevante. Todo esto se realiza con la ayuda de trabajadores locales de la cercana aldea de La Blanca. En Chilonché, se hicieron operaciones de limpieza de cuartos que habían sido destruidos, con enumeración de sillares para su posterior restitución; además de pequeños sondeos en puntos estratégicos de la acrópolis. Fueron pocos trabajos, ya que en esta campaña las investigaciones se centraron en La Blanca.
title: PROGRAMA PROPIO :PROYECTO FIN DE MÁSTER. Colaboración en el proyecto La Blanca. Guatemala

description:
Consumer Unity &Trust Society (CUTS International) is an international research, advocacy and networking organization based in India, with resource centres in Kenya, Viet Nam, the United Kingdom and Zambia. Through these centres, CUTS International engages with local civil society on issues of international trade, competition law and policy, economic regulation, consumer protection and sustainable development, with a view to enhancing consumer welfare and economic development.

ECOWAS, the Economic Community of West African States, is in the process of designing regional competition legislation and has called on member states to improve their own competition regimes. Without proper understanding and public support, however, it will be difficult for these states to implement their competition regimes. CUTS has been invited by some civil society organizations, government representatives and experts in Burkina Faso, The Gambia, Ghana, Nigeria, Sénégal and Togo to help them build the necessary capacity to bring the need for an effective competition regime into the wider public domain. This grant will allow them to do so. The project is also expected to draw the attention of the international community to the need to support competition policy and consumer protection in the region.
title: Competition and Regulation in West Africa

description:
This project is to improve practices and projects of COCD to be more accountable to their communities through listening to voices of community people, and promote their genuine participation and ownership to drive the projects. During the 3-month project period, COCD is funded to carry out design process in their existing targeted areas in Phnom Kravanh district in the climate change and livelihoods frame.

As COCD has heard positive feedback from other 2 partners of CAFOD who were funded design process, the partner seeks to improve their practices and skills in designing projects so that they can enhance the effectiveness of their projects as well as mobilise funds from existing funding agencies and new institutional donors. The partner is currently having a project in Phnom Kravanh district funded by AOP, and the project is coming to an end in June 2018. The partner is hoping to develop a quality project that will effectively address the needs of target communities and to secure continued funds from AOP.

In complementary to this design project, four COCD staff who are participating in the capacity strengthening programme with CAFOD will be able to apply learnings from the programme, and demonstrate how their capacity has been improved over time. COCD will facilitate experiences and learnings from this design process to be shared within organisation to enhance design process for all future projects.
title: Project Design in Phnom Kravanh district, Pursat

title: Australia Awards in Africa

description:
This project will provide hands-on training for approximately 30 technical experts from the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) to work on issues related to the measurement of multi-dimensional child poverty and inequality. The customized one-week training course will be held in Cairo, with post-workshop assistance to follow.

The course will combine analytical and practical approaches to measuring multi-dimensional child poverty and inequality. It will emphasize experiential learning using customized case studies, expert-facilitated group work, and hands-on analysis. Specific guidance on how to infer strategic areas of policy focus in varying contexts will emerge. This will help experts to identify policy options that will most effectively benefit children.

The Partnership for Economic Policy (PEP) network team, in collaboration with the Oxford Poverty and Human Development Initiative and UNICEF MENA Regional Office, will prepare the course and training package. IDRC will provide advice and feedback regarding content.

The training will benefit IDRC's projects on social protection policies and equity. It will also help build capacity among decision-makers and advisors to undertake effective policy strategies to address child poverty and vulnerabilities. Finally, it will enhance IDRC collaboration with policymakers in the region.
title: Regional Training Course on Multi-dimensional Child Poverty and Inequality Measurement

description:
The project is in intentions of women, girls in jail and old detainees, who are facing many difficulties of access to health services, often aggressiveness from the population and their rejection. The Association #Etoile tara Bouaré# knows this problem well and has strong relational networks. The subject is carried out through psychological support activities, donations, theatrical performances, exchange and training. It will be executed by the association and former prisoners from the city. These formerdetainees will be relays between families and detainees, they will be the main facilitators of the project.
Definitely, the number of women in prisonis increasing. Alongside this reality, the presence in our prisons of pregnant women or living with their children (some are born there) in conditions often more difficult for the maintenance of pregnancy and especially for the future of the child.
title: Etoile Tara Bouaré

The goal of the project is to improve health and living conditions in selected communities of Peru by strengthening the capacity of municipal authorities to provide water and sanitation services and by improving water and sanitation infrastructure. The project helps to strengthen the municipalities' capacity to design, operate and maintain infrastructure, as well as strengthening their administrative capacities. The capacity building is achieved through a mix of training, coaching and learning-by-doing while implementing water and sanitation projects. The project also contributes to rebuilding and rehabilitating key components of the water and sanitation infrastructure in the city of Ica following the August 2007 earthquake in Peru.
title: Water and Sanitation Capacity Building

description:
This award to Jhpiego will directly complement the activities of ISDP also implemented by Jhpiego. The PEPFAR team determined that due to award ceiling issues for ISDP and the expanded scope of PMTCT Option B+ programming that it would do a separate award to Jhpiego rather than increase funding to Jhpiego through ISDP.
Through ISDP, Jhpiego implements primary health care services in two states of Central and Western Equatoria. HIV prevention and care services are part of the basic package of primary health care in South Sudan. In its first two years, ISDP implemented integrated HTC and HIV care services in 15 clinics located in 10 counties. Although the 15 clinics had PMTCT services before, the quality of these services was severely affected after the Global Fund grants ended. 
In FY14, Jhpiego will prioritize PMTCT services in seven of the 15 clinics. Jhpiego will implement all four components of the WHO recommendations for quality PMTCT programs. Of particular note is the strategy to test and treat all pregnant women regardless of their CD4 count. This is in line with the national guideline as adopted by the Ministry of Health (MoH) from the 2013 WHO guidance. 
Jhpiego will conduct trainings and refresher courses for PMTCT providers, recruit traditional birth attendants (TBAs) to be trained to follow mother-infant pairs and, where not already in use, introduce MoH registers for data collection. This will improve data quality, record keeping for patient management and support for ANC sentinel surveillance. PEPFAR will continue to advocate for the development and implementation of training programs, particularly at the pre- and in-service level with the MoH, to strengthen human resource capacity to provide HIV care, treatment and PMTCT services.
title: Mechanism 17714 - SPPHC

description:
Oxfam:
Oxfam is a leading organization in emergency WaSH and Food Security in Mozambique since 1987.  Over the past five years Oxfam has implemented WaSH responses to benefit flood-affected populations in Sofala and Zambezia, cholera-affected populations in Sofala and Niassa, WaSH activities for east African refugees in Cabo Delgado and Nampula, and EFSL response for populations affected by three consecutive years of drought in Gaza.  In Mozambique Oxfam uses a single programmatic approach, linking activities in sustainable livelihoods, humanitarian assistance, good governance and gender for amore effective impact on beneficiaries.  In 2013, in coordination with COSACA members, Oxfam with its local partners implemented an emergency intervention to benefit more than 32,000 people in nine of the most flood-affected communities in Gaza and 8,000people in Zambezia province through seeds and tools fairs, food security (EFSL) and access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene promotion (WASH).  The total funding mobilized was $2 million from the Oxfam co-federation network and two bilateral donors.
title: Country Office 506575 Stichting Oxfam No

description:
The proposed project will tackle
problems identified above in a sustainable way and based on a wide coverage. It
is an extreme priority to encourage the improvement of habitat conditions in
these human settlements, raise awareness for environmental protection (water,
protection of green areas), and provide opportunities for young people by
enhancing their artistic skills. We should also raise awareness and work in
partnership with local governments to address these problems, contributing for
the creation of satisfactory public policies in the municipal level.

There are not similar experiences
in Trujillo. The only similar experience is the one that RASA JOVEN has
developed with the support of the UN-Habitat Urban Youth Fund. RASA is
developing a pilot of choreographic mixes (fusion break dance and local dance)
and painting houses in the upper parts of the community. The aim is to engage
youth in the community life and promote activities towards the protection of
the environment, water reuse and income generation.

This project will continue what
is being supported by the UN-Habitat Urban Youth Fund, however, in a larger
scale, reaching two districts of Trujillo. The main objective is the
consolidation of choreographic performances lead by a youth network, aligned to
the promotion of sustainable human settlements. All this involving the local
government, which will be a key partner in promoting young artists performances
and enhancing policies for risk management and environmental protection in
their communities.
title: Habitat Improvement Through Street Art And Youth Policies. A Flawless Dance Floor

description:
The Colombian malfunctioning transport and infrastructure network is one of the biggest obstacles to economic growth. Moving goods from where most of the population is located to a port is more expensive than shipping them from the port to its final destination in Asia or Europe.

This project is part of the Colombia Netherlands Water Partnership (CNWP), between the government of Colombia and the Netherlands.



The main objective of the project is to identify government strategies aimed to provide optimal conditions for the development of river transport that has high international standards harmonized with the national environment, and to provide the key elements for structuring the River Master Plan for Colombia in the components: 

1) Institutional Planning

2) River Transport Infrastructure

3) Operational Framework

4) Promotional Strategy

5) Financing.



The Dutch assistance primarily has to focus on the following task:

How to use and integrate the knowledge of the different study groups in order to achieve the objectives:

1. Design of the methodology

2. Guide and manage the different study groups

3. Integrate the results

4. Monitor progress and planning

5. Identify and organize the specific areas for Dutch assistance

6. Design the table of contents for the Master Plan for Flood Control

7. Design the work plan for the implementation of this Master Plan.



The project has been carried out by Arcadis and partners Stichting Taalcentrum-VU and Concorde Group Global Translation Services.
title: Masterplan Inland Water Transport

description:
Following the July 2006 Israeli war, UN-Habitat Lebanon implemented a project titled “Good governance for enhanced post-war reconstruction in South Lebanon” which aimed at enhancing the capacities of affected families and municipalities to better manage the reconstruction process. Within this project, three Regional Technical Offices (RTOs) were established in three targeted Unions of Municipalities (UoMs); Tyre, Bint Jbeil and Jabal Amel. The RTO's engineers and field officers, being part of the local communities, were able, in a short period of time, to mobilize and immediately provide assistance to affected families as well as to concerned municipalities. By assisting the municipalities with rapid technical assessments of the buildings needing reconstruction work, and providing information and guidelines for house owners with ABCs in repair work, the RTOs contributed to a broad and swift rehabilitation process with the local actors at the steering wheel. 


Based on the previous experience UN-Habitat now replicates the RTO model to support the efforts of providing shelter and services for Syrian refugees as well as meeting the needs of the house communities, by enhancing the role of local authorities. In the first pilot phase two RTOs will be established under the mandate of two Unions of Municipalities within the Saida/Zahrani and Chouf districts. After the pilot RTOs are put in place and anticipated system and mechanisms tested, the approach will be applied in more Unions with further geographical outreach. The aim is to establish a model that could work within all Unions of Municipalities in Lebanon, covering more than 800 of the 1000 Municipalities in the country. To ensure that the project is able to rapidly apply the model in new Unions, a second batch of another three Unions of Municipalities is identified. 
This proposed Project, with a focus on enhancing the involvement of municipalities in responding to the needs of Syrian refugees, would i) complement the efforts of the Government, UNHCR, and other UN, national and international agencies, ii) accelerate the assistance process addressed to refugees, and iii) reduce the tension between host communities and refugees.The goal of the project is to respond to the immediate needs of Syrian refugees and host communities in different areas of Lebanon while laying the foundation for medium and long term sustainable solutions. 

In line with the project goal, the proposed action is planned to achieve two main objectives: 
- Accelerate the accommodation process of refugee families through the active involvement of municipalities and unions of municipalities in identifying, assessing and facilitating sound shelter facilities that comply with UNHCR standards and norms. 

- Support host communities through the implementation of sound projects that would respond to community groups needs and would enhance the delivery of basic urban services taking into account the existing and forthcoming numbers of refugees.


The strategy would include the following:
At the national level, UN-Habitat has been coordinating and will continue collaboration with UNHCR, the Ministry of Social Affairs (MoSA), the Ministry of Interior and Municipalities (MoIM) and other concerned governmental institutions and International agencies. This is being done through taking part in donor meetings as well as working groups, mainly shelter and WASH, and inter-agency meetings.
At the regional levels, in addition to municipalities and unions of municipalities, bureaus and representatives of government and international and UN agencies would constantly be engaged in the project processes, notably the Qaimmaqams (Heads of district/Caza leading the regional security cells), UNHCR and other international agencies regional offices. The project will also collaborate and complement on-going and recent UN initiatives in the targeted areas dealing with issues related to Syrian refugees.


The project will set up a model whereby unions of municipalities, municipalities, and communities are actively and constantly engaged in responding to the needs of the Syrian refugees. Partnerships with key local actors represent a core value for this project. The involvement of local actors will prevent possible bottleneck situations in the response, as it will not be limited to agencies already concerned with overstretched capacities.
title: Enhancing The Role Of Union Of Municipalities To Respond To Refugees' And Host Communities' Needs: Hand Washing Campaign

description: Award Description - The description for this item is GENERAL SERVICES

In Ghana over 40% of 9 million inhabitants has no access to safe drinking water facilities. The Water Health Ghana WASH Project wants to establish 85 Water Health Centres (WHCs) in 85 Districts, Municipalities and Metropolitan Areas throughout the country and provide 650 thousand inhabitants of underserviced communities with clean and reliable drinking water, improving hygiene with WASH practices in communities and at schools.

Drinking water supply in Ghana is much under pressure due to lack of sufficient water resources, limited infrastructure, irregular supply and unreliable, underperforming or even non-operating water facilities and services. With a considerably large proportion of the population lacking access to safe drinking water and faced with poor sanitation, child mortality and waterborne diseases are much prevalent.

The project addresses key challenges to improve access to safe and purified drinking water in both rural and peri-urban underserved communities with the construction of community-based water service facilities, so-called Decentralised Water Health Centres (DWHCs). The Centres include drinking and portable water taps, an office, a filtration system, storage tanks and toilet facilities, mainly for personnel. The project wants un(der)served communities to be strongly involved and gradually take over the control and ownership of the DWHCs.
title: WaterHealth Ghana WASH Project - 2

description: Our project has trained 14 local health care providers called brigadistas to provide basic health care to campesino families in 10 remote mountain villages. Brigadistas administer first aid and medications from mini-pharmacies called botiquines. Each month, our Nicaraguan doctor visits each village for consultations. Our local nurse refills the botiquines and meets with the brigadistas. Each brigadista sees 30-50 patients per month, in 10 villages: 300-500 total monthly, or 3600-5000 annually.
title: Health Care for 3,600 Nicaraguan Campesinos
